t: Proverbs 25
Further Wise Sayings of Solomon
These*p also are*i proverbs of Solomon which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied:
It*ipn is*i the glory of God to conceal a matter, But*ld the glory of kings is*i to search out a matter.
As*iln the heavens for height and the earth for depth, So*ld the heart of kings is*i unsearchable.
Take*ln away the dross from silver, And*ld it will go to the silversmith for*i jewelry.
Take*ld away the wicked from before the king, And*ld his throne will be established in righteousness.
Do*ln not exalt yourself in the presence of the king, And*ld do not stand in the place of the great;
For*ld it*i is*i better that he say to you, “Come*ld up here,” Than*ld that you should be put lower in the presence of the prince, Whom*ld your eyes have seen.
Do*ln not go hastily to court; For*ld what will you do in the end, When*ld your neighbor has put you to shame?
Debate*ld your case with your neighbor, And*ld do not disclose the secret to another;
Lest*ld he who hears it*i expose your shame, And*ld your reputation be ruined.
A*ln word fitly spoken is*i like*i apples of gold In*ld settings of silver.
Like*ild an earring of gold and an ornament of fine gold Is*ild a wise rebuker to an obedient ear.
Like*ln the cold of snow in time of harvest Is*ild a faithful messenger to those who send him, For*ld he refreshes the soul of his masters.
Whoever*ln falsely boasts of giving Is*ild like*i clouds and wind without rain.
By*ln long forbearance a ruler is persuaded, And*ld a gentle tongue breaks a bone.
Have*ln you found honey? Eat*ld only as much as you need, Lest*ld you be filled with it and vomit.
Seldom*ln set foot in your neighbor’s house, Lest*ld he become weary of you and hate you.
A*ln man who bears false witness against his neighbor Is*ild like*i a club, a sword, and a sharp arrow.
Confidence*ln in an unfaithful man*i in time of trouble Is*ild like*i a bad tooth and a foot out of joint.
Like*iln one who takes away a garment in cold weather, And*ild like*i vinegar on soda, Is*ild one who sings songs to a heavy heart.
If*ln your enemy is hungry, give him bread to eat; And*ld if he is thirsty, give him water to drink;
For*ld so*i you will heap coals of fire on his head, And*ld the Lord*s will reward you.
The*ln north wind brings forth rain, And*ld a backbiting tongue an angry countenance.
It*iln is*i better to dwell in a corner of a housetop, Than*ld in a house shared with a contentious woman.
As*iln cold water to a weary soul, So*ld is*i good news from a far country.
A*ln righteous man*i who falters before the wicked Is*ild like*i a murky spring and a polluted well.
It*iln is*i not good to eat much honey; So*ld to seek one’s own glory is*i not*i glory.
Whoever*ln has*i no rule over his own spirit Is*ild like*i a city broken down, without walls.
